## Terminal Access & Performance

Roo Code executes commands in managed terminal instances with real-time output capture, integrated with VS Code's terminal system for optimal performance and security. The system implements a fallback mechanism for executing terminal commands if VSCode terminal shell integration fails.

Key terminal performance features include:

- Line truncation that keeps approximately 20% of the head and 80% of the tail of output, inserting an omission marker to stay under limits
- Character truncation that keeps ~20% of the head and ~80% of the tail to prevent memory issues from very long lines
- Progress bar collapsing that processes carriage returns and backspaces to keep only the final state

## File Handling Performance

For file operations, the read_file tool automatically manages token budgets to prevent context overruns when reading large files. The system efficiently streams only requested line ranges for better performance.

The write_to_file tool has specific performance considerations: Operations become significantly slower with larger files, and it's much slower and less efficient than apply_diff for modifying existing files.

Roo Code has also offloaded expensive count token operations to a web worker for better performance.

Recent improvements include a major refactor of the terminal architecture to address critical issues including terminal overload and gray screen problems.

**Interaction Modes:**
Roo Code offers a variety of customizable modes, such as Code Mode for routine coding tasks, Architect Mode for designing systems, Ask Mode for posing questions, Debug Mode for resolving issues, and user-defined Custom Modes tailored for specific tasks.

**Core Functionality:**
- It possesses the ability to directly read and write files in the workspace, run terminal commands, and automate actions in web browsers.

### **Claude Code**
Claude Code is a polished, enterprise-ready tool from Anthropic that you use mostly through your terminal, like a command-line interface (CLI) tool. With support for models like Claude 3.5 Sonnet and Claude 3 Opus, it delivers contextual reasoning and multi-file understanding.

**Strengths:**
- Wins on versatility - you can use it as a CLI command, integrate it into shell scripts, add it to automation workflows, and run it in diverse environments

I found several GitHub issues related to Roo Code's multi-file operations and context window problems. Here's a summary of the key issues:

## Context Window Issues with Multi-File Operations

### 1. **Files Larger Than Context Window** (Issue #4186)
Roo can load files into context that exceed the model's context window, causing auto-condensing to loop indefinitely. Users expect Roo to recognize when a file exceeds the context window size and either abort, log, or truncate the file.

### 2. **Multi-File Repository Handling Issues** (Issue #7438)
The LLM cannot handle multi-file repositories coherently, and Roo drowns the LLM in unnecessary mode complexity, making multi-file operations unreliable. Users report that even simple requests take 3-4 minutes and fail to complete properly.

### 3. **Context Window Size Setting Ignored** (Issue #4475)
Roo Code appears to ignore the Context Window Size parameter in OpenAI Compatible settings. The setting doesn't limit tokens sent to vLLM regardless of what value is configured.

### 4. **Directory Context Issues** (Issue #2216)
When using @ context mentions for directories, the contents of every file in the mentioned directory are included in the prompt, which can quickly overwhelm the context window.

### Tips from Documentation
Users can adjust the File read auto-truncate threshold setting to manage large files and reduce context usage. Additionally, if you hit the input length and max tokens exceed context limit error, you can recover by deleting a message, rolling back to a checkpoint, or switching to a model with a longer context window.

These issues highlight ongoing challenges with context management when working with multiple files in Roo Code.

## Claude Code MCP Support Overview

Claude Code can connect to hundreds of external tools and data sources through the Model Context Protocol (MCP), an open source standard for AI-tool integrations.

### Key Features

**1. Tool and Data Source Integration**
MCP servers give Claude Code access to your tools, databases, and APIs.

**2. Resource Management with @ Mentions**
MCP servers can expose resources that you can reference using @ mentions, similar to how you reference files. Type @ in your prompt to see available resources from all connected MCP servers.

**3. Output Token Management**
Claude Code displays a warning when any MCP tool output exceeds 10,000 tokens, with a configurable limit adjustable using the MAX_MCP_OUTPUT_TOKENS environment variable and a default maximum of 25,000 tokens.

**4. Multiple Configuration Scopes**
MCP servers can be configured at three different scope levels, each serving distinct purposes for managing server accessibility and sharing.

**5. Plugin MCP Server Support**
Servers start when plugin enables with support for stdio, SSE, and HTTP transports.(no content)Benefits include bundled distribution with tools and servers packaged together, automatic setup with no manual MCP configuration needed, and team consistency where everyone gets the same tools when plugin is installed.

**6. Enterprise Management Options**
Claude Code supports exclusive control with managed-mcp.json to deploy a fixed set of MCP servers that users cannot modify, and policy-based control with allowlists/denylists to allow users to add their own servers while restricting which ones are permitted.

**7. Multiple Transport Types**
MCPs can run as external processes, connect via HTTP/SSE, or execute directly within your SDK application.

Based on the search results, here are the key issues, limitations, and complaints regarding Roo Code's MCP integration:

## Major Issues and Bugs

**Version-Specific Connectivity Problems**
Users report that Roo Code versions 3.9.0 and above introduced bugs that break MCP functionality, with versions 3.8.6 and below working correctly. When adding new local stdio MCP server definitions on Windows, Roo Code fails to connect or recognize them, resulting in errors like "No connection found for server" and "Server [server_name] with source global not found".

**AI Refusing to Use MCP Tools**
Users report that even when Sequential Thinking and Memory MCP servers are installed and explicitly mentioned in prompts, Roo refuses to use them, claiming it doesn't have access.

**UI Display Issues**
In versions 3.9.0 and above, the MCP section becomes blank even with proper configuration, and the MCPs themselves are not functional, causing Roo to perform alternative actions instead of using the configured MCP tools.

## Limitations

**Lack of Granular Control**
When modes have "Use MCP" enabled in their "Available Tools", ALL installed MCP servers and their tools become available to the AI, with no restrictions functionality. While native modes maintain design parity by not allowing tool customization, custom modes would benefit from MCP server restrictions to enable specialized configurations.

**No Auto-Approval for Resources**
Users currently cannot auto-approve MCP resources like they can with MCP tools, creating workflow friction when repeatedly accessing the same trusted resources.

**Model Complexity Issues**
Models can struggle with complex tool use, leading to errors, hallucinations, or repetitive loops, as observed in Roo Code GitHub issues.

These issues suggest that while MCP integration is a powerful feature, it has experienced significant regression issues in recent versions and lacks some user-requested flexibility features.

# **BRUTAL HONEST COMPARISON: Roo Code vs Claude Code**

## **TL;DR - Which One Sucks Less?**

**Claude Code** = More powerful, faster, better automation, but **expensive as hell** with predatory usage limits and file editing bugs that kill your flow.

**Roo Code** = Cheaper (BYOK), more control, better for complex multi-file tasks, but **crashes constantly**, burns through tokens like crazy, and context management is broken.

---

## **1. WHAT EACH TOOL ACTUALLY DOES WELL**

### **Claude Code Strengths:**

âœ… **Intelligence & Reasoning** - [Claude Opus 4.5 scores 80.9% on SWE-bench Verified](https://dev.to/nodeshiftcloud/claude-4-opus-vs-sonnet-benchmarks-and-dev-workflow-with-claude-code-11fa), first model to break 80%. [Terminal-bench: 59.3%](https://apidog.com/blog/claude-code-vs-codex-cli/), crushing Gemini (54.2%) and GPT (47.6%).

âœ… **CLI Automation** - [Scriptable as CLI tool for enterprise workflows](https://www.arsturn.com/blog/roo-vs-claude-code-which-ai-is-best-for-large-codebases). Can integrate into GitHub Actions, automate PR reviews, documentation generation. [Roo can't match this](https://berryhill.dev/posts/claude-code-versus-roo-code-which-ai-coding-tool-is-right-for-you).

âœ… **No Rate Limiting (on CLI)** - [Unlimited usage on API](https://slashdot.org/software/comparison/Claude-Code-vs-Roo-Code/), unlike subscription plans.

âœ… **Surgical Code Edits** - [Makes "surgical, necessary corrections without fluff"](https://www.arsturn.com/blog/roo-vs-claude-code-which-ai-is-best-for-large-codebases), reducing bugs.

### **Roo Code Strengths:**

âœ… **Multi-Mode System** - [Architect (planning) â†’ Code (execution) â†’ Debug](https://docs.roocode.com/basic-usage/using-modes). [Mode switching prevents scope creep](https://www.datacamp.com/tutorial/roo-code).

âœ… **Model Agnostic (BYOK)** - [Supports OpenRouter, Anthropic, DeepSeek, Gemini](https://arnav.tech/beyond-copilot-cursor-and-claude-code-the-unbundled-coding-ai-tools-stack). Use DeepSeek-R1 and [cut costs by 97%](https://www.qodo.ai/blog/roo-code-vs-cline/).

âœ… **Open Source & Customizable** - [Fork of Cline with enhanced features](https://www.qodo.ai/blog/roo-code-vs-cline/). Full transparency.
